reviewText:
Nidhogg is a small game developed by an indie developer Messhof. While the game isn’t the longest one I have ever played, it is definitely THE best local multiplayer game I have played in a long time. You can literally spend countless hours playing the local multiplayer against your friends.

In Nidhogg there is only one objective , kill your opponent by out-stabbing them by using only three sets of stances, high, middle and low. Maneuvers such as, rolling, dive-kicking, neck-snapping and sword-throwing are also at your disposal. While it may sound simple at first, the game is really hard to master, and sometimes it gets a little bit frustrating when you get stabbed couple times in a row.

After you kill your enemy you have to run to the right in order to advance to next level, the enemy can do the same thing, if you get killed, he can run to the opposite direction, this will get you back to the previous screen, and this gets really annoying because sometimes the enemy instead of fighting you, will just run past you just to get you back to the previous screen. Each ‘level’ is divided into couple smaller ones. In single player, there is a total of 17 AI opponents, the first one being the easiest and the last one, the toughest(I don’t know if that’s true but when I’ve played it, the game got harder every time with each AI opponent). At the end of each level your character is eaten by a giant dragon-like creature, by the name of Nidhogg, you can’t avoid it though(trust me, I’ve tried), I don’t know what’s the point of that but It’s kind of hilarious and random.

The art style is what I love the most about this game, it has that surreal look to it, kind of like Hotline Miami. The player animations are also worth mentioning because of how smooth and realistic they are, and also it feels really satisfying when you stab someone.

On the other hand, the game also has some flaws, one of them is the online multiplayer, it is seriously lacking in features and is very unstable, I kept being disconnected from matches, and I have experienced serious lag during several online matches. You can’t even properly communicate with your opponent because the chat can’t handle longer messages.

As I have said before, the single-player consists of 17 AI opponents, which is great but the same can’t be said about the level variety, there is only 3 or 4 different levels which are re-used during the 17 battles in the single-player. I really wish that there was more variety in level design, maybe we’ll get them in later updates.

Nonetheless, If you enjoy playing games with your friends then this game is for you but If you don’t like the local multiplayer I would still recommend sure the game isn’t very long, but the multiplayer is still there, it might be a bit lackluster but who knows maybe the devs will add some new features to the online multiplayer.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: Fast, frantic, and ludicrously silly, Nidhogg is one of the best party games I've played in forever. With a couple of friends on the couch, this turns into a hilarious game of wits and reflexes as you try to outmanuver and out-fence your opponents. Simple controls and gorgeous graphics combine with excellent music and sound design to present a simple, rewarding experience. While $15 is a bit steep considering how bare the content is (4 levels and a very barebones singleplayer), if you can pick this game up on sale it is well worth the money. The next time you and a couple of friends are wondering how to kill the time, challenging them to a fencing match for the right to be devoured by a great beast is a fantastic way to do it.

reviewText: Nidhogg is one of the most enjoyable games I've ever played. It's complex and simple all at the same time. reviewText: I'm definitely recommending that you play Nidhogg. The controls and mechanics are simple enough for you to learn them quickly, but they also have enough depth for complex, skill-based play. At first, fighting doesn't appear complicated, but there is a lot going on. Positioning is crucial; standing above your opponent or blocking a doorway can make all the diffence. You also have a few different ways to approach fighting. Fencing is an option, but you could also try tossing your sword and rushing ahead for some melee attacks. One of my favorite tricks is playing chicken"; I throw my sword and charge ahead

reviewText:
Full review: http://www.cublikefoot.com/review/nidhogg-game-review/

Nidhogg, also referred to as Fencing Simulator 2014 (by me, at least), is an excellent example of what a casual, multiplayer indie game should be. Be prepared to engage in very fast-paced swordplay, with friends of course.

The objective in Nidhogg is very simple: reach the end of the map on the enemy's side before he/she can reach your end of the map. Upon reaching the end of the map, you're promptly eaten by an Alaskan Bullworm. No idea why, but that signals your victory. However, a lone enemy stands in the way, ready to commence fencing at any given moment. This is where the real fun in the game lies, the fighting. Well, that's basically what the game is, so there's a plus.

There are three stances that one can take whilst wielding a sword in Nidhogg: Low, mid, and high. If your opponent attacks you low, and your stance is low, then you block their attack. This applies to the other two stances as well. There's also a stance that you can take if you just hold your sword up high. This stance is only used to prepare for throwing the sword, which, when thrown, can be deflected if your opponent has a mid or high stance active. Once you're without a sword, you must revert to your fists, which don't always help out much. However, you can pick up a fallen sword.

The game has a very minimalistic style to it. The characters are very low-res, solid-color sprites. This is an interesting style for such a game and it does add to the fun a bit on a certain stage, the Cloud stage. Because of the game's style, it is very difficult to see where each character is on this map, which is both a good and bad thing! All that said, the game does have one massive flaw. That flaw being the complete lack of content. For a game that has been in development for several years, I would at least expect more than four maps. Four years and only four maps? Very disappointing.

Nidhogg, overall, is just an excellent game. Highly recommended if you have a friend to play it with!

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fz-9jQTaBKI

reviewText:
When first watching this game be played, I thought it was an amusing idea and certainly heralded a fun concept for fighting games. It then took nearly three years for the game to be released, and it kind of slipped off my radar. Upon launching on Steam for $15, I was immediately taken aback at what seemed a steep price for what I considered to be a very simple and one dimensional game.
I'm glad to say that I was wrong. While over a friend's house, an impromtu Nidhogg tournament broke out and three hours and many laughs later, we all went home to buy the game for ourselves.
The game contains a dark sense of humor, simplistic but stylish retro visuals, and extraordinarily tight controls. It is compatible with three out of four of the controllers I have tested with it, and it's online is stable. I would reccomend playing against human opponents as much as possible (preferably in a hotseat fashion as the reactions of your live opponent is part of the attraction), but the AI is perfectly servicable for practicing your fighting strategy, if maybe just a little cheap every now and then.
For $15, if you play games with your friends often, this is a very reasonable and frankly excellent purchase, and I don't think you'll regret it!

reviewText:
First and foremost: Get a friend to play with you on the same TV. Trust me. Get a few friends, a small party. This game is at its best when you have a crew of folks with you playing tournaments.

It's a very simple game that's damn near impossible to master, and every single match with a human opponent can offer more range of emotion than your average title simply from your own progress -- or loss of.

If you're only interested in single player, this game will SEVERELY disappoint at just four maps and very few modes. However, these maps are finely tuned and feature everything you'd need for a game like this, and the modes are just interesting enough to throw a curveball to your opponent. So go in with the thought that you're going to find someone to play with. Trust me.

reviewText: One of the most entertaining fighting games and IT'S NOT EVEN A FIGHTING GAME! It does however have everything you'd find in a typical 2D tournament fighter: mind games between players, footsies, yomi, cross-ups, ect. This game is best enjoyed between 2 people so spending the money for the double pace is well worth the extra coin. The icing on the cake is that it only takes about 7 seconds to download and 1 or 2 minutes to install minor updates! Seriously, this could have existed 30 years ago on the Atari 2600 (Okay, maybe not, but if you see the style of the graphics then you'll understand why). If your either casual player,  an indie fan, or fighting game veterian straight out of the arcades, than Nidhogg is the game for you.

reviewText: Nidhogg is a very simple game that is hard to be extremely good at. There's a limited amount of things you can do and it's kind of beautiful how there are counters and weaknesses to everything you do. You can only do 4 actions, really. Attack, roll, throw sword or divekick. The most advanced move is you can press up and down to change the level of your fencing sword. And if you change the level of your sword into the level of your opponent's fencing sword, it disarms them. Maybe being the buttonmasher is an advantage? I haven't quite figured it out, but this is a game to play against any friend.\n\nThis is a 1v1 combat game. If you kill your opponent, you are allowed to move forward to pan the screen in your direciton. You must run your designated direction for a few rooms to 'win the match' and choose another level. When you kill your opponent they'll repeatedly spawn in front of you. A stalward guardian of your path to your victory. Defeat them over and over the become the champion.

reviewText:
Fast paced, ability based fighting game.

Although at first glance it seems a bit limited, because of the small number of levels and simplicity of controls, the game is extremely flexible and allows for a wide range of playing styles and options. It also allows to modify gameplay options to make gameplay even more varied.

It's best enjoyed by playing two players in the same screen, I have still to check the online mode.

Personal Experience: I once played this with an entire group of actual fencers. Although it obviously lacks the depth of real fencing, we had a real good time and felt the combat was actually compelling and similar to fencing. Except the victory part, of course, they are still puzzled by it.

reviewText:
THE NIDHOGG MUST FEED. A SNACKRIFICE AWAITS.
The question is, will it be you, or the other guy?
Nidhogg is ostensibly a fencing game. But this appraisal is kind of misleading; it's definitely a game that features fencing, and the fencing is both simple and intense in the way many early-era 2 player games were (like Swashbuckler and Championship Karate). But there are a number of things going on here that you wouldn't see anybody getting away with in a proper fencing match, and that's where things start getting interesting. Throwing swords, sweeping the leg, and jump kicking the other dude in the chest are among the other tricks the Yellow Swoardsman and Orange Swordsman have at their disposal.
But wait; the match isn't won when your enemy's body is at your feet. Victory is only achieved by reaching the end of the level, far past your nemesis' starting position. And you'll find several more of him waiting where the first one came from.
So it's like fencing, even when it contains things other than fencing. Nidhogg is a must-play for anyone with a friend to play with, or hell, train your cat extremely well and play it with him.

reviewText: Nidhogg is a great game where two players engage in a fencing duel of throwing, kicking, and stabing. This game can easy for two players to play on one computer (for instance one player using w,a,s,d and another up, down, left, right). You can set up tournaments where players can battle in a series of battles determining the best player. Nidhogg includes has a single-player mode. In singleplayer you fight different computers in hope of getting the fastest time. One great feature is variants where you can customize the gameplay for a new experience. Variants include time limit, low gravity, turbo mode, slow mode, boomerang swords, and more. I would highly recomend this game for any group of two or more people.

reviewText: I think Nidhogg is an extremely fun game. It's combat is suprisingly deep for what it is and plays out gracefully against friends or against AI. The stages are also well designed and beautiful without a hypnotic soundtrack. However, despite being a pixel art game, Nidhogg is about as demanding as full HD 2D games such as Battleblock Theater. This wouldn't really be that big of issue, except for the fact that the game's logic is written in reference to frames instead of milliseconds meaning that if the framerate goes below 60 then the game will actually slow down which can be quite jarring. On the whole though, Nidhogg is a simple fighting game great for playing multiplayer or single player and I would reccomend it to anyone as soon as it goes on sale. That being said, if you have a lower-end PC be aware of the above issues.

reviewText:
Fast paced, ability based fighting game.

Although at first glance it seems a bit limited, because of the small number of levels and simplicity of controls, the game is extremely flexible and allows for a wide range of playing styles and options. It also allows to modify gameplay options to make gameplay even more varied.

It's best enjoyed by playing two players in the same screen, I have still to check the online mode.

Personal Experience: I once played this with an entire group of actual fencers. Although it obviously lacks the depth of real fencing, we had a real good time and felt the combat was actually compelling and similar to fencing. Except the victory part, of course, they are still puzzled by it.

reviewText:
Do not buy this game for online play. You will be disappointed.

I love looking for new games to play with friends, and I was ecstatic to see this finally released. The gameplay is fantastically unique: You fight past your opponent to run to their 'endzone.' Killing them is not always necessary; you can just run past them, but it'll usually get you killed. After all, combat is what the game was made for.

When fencing, there are three different stances you can take (low, mid, high), which can be used for parrying, or, if swift enough, disarming. But if you get disarmed, you can still roll under your opponent, kick them off their feet, snap their neck, and take their sword. But then they respawn at the other end again! So here's where you just chuck your sword into their head and pick it up again as you run past.

This is one of very few games where I have wanted to practice different techniques, guards, and attacks. The depth of gameplay is great (Even if there are only four stages), and the idea is unique. The one downside is the online play, which, more often than not, gives players too much lag to even be playable.

I wouldn't recommend this if you don't have friends to play with locally, but if you do, enjoy!

reviewText: I haven't had that much time to play it yet, but to be honest, it's not like you need to log 1200 hours into this game to know what you're getting. So, what are you getting with Nidhogg? You're getting a game that, at it's core, is simple, but provides copious amounts of fun. It's not an epic, open-world adventure. It's simply a side-scrolling game of tug-of-war with old-school inspiration and it delivers. I would recommend this game to anyone that considers it.

reviewText:
Before you start playing this game, don't be confused, LOCAL multiplayer is really it's strong suit. Now I don't have many hours played on my account, but I've played this game plenty on a friend's, and it really is an excellent game.

It's definitely a game of skill. No outside forces are going to impact whether or not you come out the victor, it's simply you against your opponent, and occasionally taking advantage of your surroundings. The swordplay is easy to get used to but hard to master, and when you snap the neck of an enemy that's on the ground, it's amazingly satisfying. The visuals are a retro style done right, and the music and sound effects make the game come alive. One of the best local multiplayer experiences I've ever had.

However, connections with online multiplayer seem to be giving other people problems. (I don't have experience with this myself, as I've only played it locally) so if this is a turn-off for you, keep that in mind.

If the local multiplayer experience is enough to warrant the $15 for you, go for it. If not, get the game on sale. One way or another, Don't pass up on this game.

reviewText: The combat is ridiculously nuanced and satisfying.  Sure, there's not much content, but the combat is just so good.  Grab it on sale, for sure.\n\nMy gaming friends had been looking for a fighting game to turn to as our standard duke-it-out kinda game.  We'd tried SF4, Injustice, and MK9.  One guy picked Nidhogg up on PSN, and it's become the game we were searching for.  You don't need a huge cast of characters, you don't even need much in the way of graphics.  Just make the combat mechanics solid.

reviewText:
This isn't no slashy-stabby sword fighty gamey. Well, it is, but it's different. This, while being ironically pixelated, has a more realistic style of fighting. You can block, parry, stab, drop, spin, twirl,  lunge, even throw your dang sword at your opponent. The only downside to this is you realize you would be helpless in a real sword fight.

10/10 Would cry again

P.S. The ending to each level is terrifying. I nearly cried the first time I saw it. Why the developers decided to name the game after that horrific creature is a mystery.

reviewText:
Nidhogg will be some of the best fun you'll ever have in local multiplayer. Controls are easy enough that anyone can pick it up and play it well after a few minutes of either seeing someone else play, or doing so themselves.

Nidhogg, much like Divekick, manages to deliver an extremely rich and gripping experience within a limited framework of mechanics and makes for an excellent spectator sport. If you can get the controllers and people to play with, Nidhogg is a must buy.

Also bunnyhops. And worms. Those are fun too.

reviewText: Atari-tier murder fencing, I approve!  In addition, the focus on positioning as a means to fulfill your victory condition is an interesting choice for a game's standard mode of play.  While this is a game containing combat, it is moreso a game of competitive movement management.  While it has some problems, mostly collision properties on the win screen, none of them seem to interfere with the core gameplay.  I am of the opinion that Nidhogg is a simple but elegantly designed piece.

reviewText: This is an amazingly addictive and fun platforming game. It mixes swordplay and smooth platforming to make an awesome game. The fact that it supports local and global multiplayer only adds to the ridiculousness you can have. reviewText:
It took me a while to understand this game. It seemed clunky, weird, too based on random chance and the luck of finding an opening as I charged blindly forward. I didn't get what I was doing wrong. Then, on my third run through the wilds level, my opponent and I both disarmed one another simultaneously. I didn't have a weapon, and neither did he. So I did what seemed sane: I tried to stab him anyways. And we started boxing. Then he punched me backwards into the crop fields, where I had seen my weapon land. Frantically, I searched the stalks of wheat, looking for the familiar silver glint of my weapon. Behind me, he leapt into the air, ready to land upon me where I lay and smash my face into the dirt that would be my unceremonius grave. And at the last possible moment, my hand met the cold steel of my blade, and I spun, holding my weapon high —

He landed squarely on the tip of sword, violently impaled by his own momentum. And in that moment, I understood. This game was exactly as frantic, exactly as crazy and snap-reflex-based as a real fencing match, between real swordsmen. The controls might not have the finesse of an actual human arm holding an epee, but the mechanics, the pacing; these are pitch-perfect, and evoke the same thrilling adrenaline rush that whipping an actual rapier around in a clumsy attempt at defense gave me in my teenage fencing lessons (my local community center offered some pretty rad summer programs). The key is to treat combat in Nidhogg with the same sort of gravity you would in real life. Take small, inching steps toward your enemy. Change stances freely, and attack opportunistically, when given a wide opening. And only throw your sword at the oppenent when it's the only move you've got left.

It's possible to beat Nidhogg without really knowing how to play it. The game is pretty forgiving, and you have an unlimited number of attempts for each stage, meaning you can essentially grind your way towards victory if you're really determined. But it's immensely satisfying to clear a level without losing a life by trouncing the bevy of foes that stand in your way one-by-one. So practice up, and prove you've got what it takes to be a winner.

reviewText:
Do not buy this game for online play. You will be disappointed.

I love looking for new games to play with friends, and I was ecstatic to see this finally released. The gameplay is fantastically unique: You fight past your opponent to run to their 'endzone.' Killing them is not always necessary; you can just run past them, but it'll usually get you killed. After all, combat is what the game was made for.

When fencing, there are three different stances you can take (low, mid, high), which can be used for parrying, or, if swift enough, disarming. But if you get disarmed, you can still roll under your opponent, kick them off their feet, snap their neck, and take their sword. But then they respawn at the other end again! So here's where you just chuck your sword into their head and pick it up again as you run past.

This is one of very few games where I have wanted to practice different techniques, guards, and attacks. The depth of gameplay is great (Even if there are only four stages), and the idea is unique. The one downside is the online play, which, more often than not, gives players too much lag to even be playable.

I wouldn't recommend this if you don't have friends to play with locally, but if you do, enjoy!

reviewText:
Before you start playing this game, don't be confused, LOCAL multiplayer is really it's strong suit. Now I don't have many hours played on my account, but I've played this game plenty on a friend's, and it really is an excellent game.

It's definitely a game of skill. No outside forces are going to impact whether or not you come out the victor, it's simply you against your opponent, and occasionally taking advantage of your surroundings. The swordplay is easy to get used to but hard to master, and when you snap the neck of an enemy that's on the ground, it's amazingly satisfying. The visuals are a retro style done right, and the music and sound effects make the game come alive. One of the best local multiplayer experiences I've ever had.

However, connections with online multiplayer seem to be giving other people problems. (I don't have experience with this myself, as I've only played it locally) so if this is a turn-off for you, keep that in mind.

If the local multiplayer experience is enough to warrant the $15 for you, go for it. If not, get the game on sale. One way or another, Don't pass up on this game.

reviewText:
This game is a blast to play!  The singleplayer is fine, but the meat and potatoes of this game is when you're facing a human opponent either online or locally.  The online can use a bit of work because some matches can be pretty laggy.  However, when you do get in to a match and everything works, it really works.  Still, the netcode needs improvement and I hope the fixes for that come sooner rather than later.

There's a lot of hidden depth to the gameplay as well.  You have to decide when it's right to let yourself die in order to respawn in front of your opponent before they make it to the next screen.  When is it the right time to make a break for it to get to the next screen?  When you decide to let yourself die in order to respawn as a barrier for your opponent, is there is even enough time for you to respawn in front of them?  Should I hold on to my sword, or should throw it and make a run for it hoping it distracts the opponent? These are some of the thoughts that will constantly be running through your head while playing this game and it's made all the more intense when facing off against a human opponent.

I also really dig the old-school Atari 2600-esque look of the game.  The use of colours makes the levels look really nice and I just like the simplicity of it.  The super colourful neon blood is also prety great!

The soundtrack to the game is also fantastic!  Each of the 4 levels in the game has a unique song that plays in the background and it makes the one on one battle so much more enjoyable.

I definitely recommend this game to anyone who wants a lot of local and online (when it's properly working 100% of the time) MP fun!

reviewText: Between the parrying, disarming, dodging, rolling, wall-jumping, punching, sweep-kicking, throwing your sword in rage to kill a fleeing adversary, having the satisfaction of idly jiggling your sword into your impaled foe's innards, and ultimately coming down to fisticuffs until you tear out your opponent's heart (or, as so often happens, they tear YOUR heart out), this game allows the players and spectators alike to enjoy the chaos of swordfighting in a 2-D world in good ol' fashioned, nitty-gritty one-on-one PvP, done arcade style and done right. Highly recommended for a game to settle a beef, make wagers, record the inevitable rage of at least one of the combatants, or just to pass the time with a gruesome yet addicting game of pixelated tug-of-war (just replacing the ropes with rapiers). 9.5/10 (because there is just a tad bit of lag occasionally online, but that's partly my weak internet connection).

reviewText:
There's something to be said about a game that feels as balanced as Nidhogg does. Every offense has its countering defensive stance, every defense has an offensive move to get around it, and none of them require any more or less effort than the other, making it a simple game of preparation, reflexes, and psychology; the true essence of a fighting game.

The graphics could be described as 'minimal', or it could be described as 'clear'. I choose to view it the latter way. All necessary information is communicated in an understandable fashion without sacrificing artistic integrity. Daedelus' soundtrack provides an excellent support to the atmosphere of the game and its individual levels, from the intense and aggressive Wilds, to the tense and deliberate Mines, and the quick and nimble Clouds.

Nidhogg's design is flawless in nearly every aspect, the only regrets being the lack of content. But why should you care about that, when you can throw a sword at someone to force them to block high, roll underneath them while grabbing a sword, then stab them in the back in a series of grand maneuvers that will make you feel like a god among men?

reviewText: I strongly recommend this game. Even with the people complaining about lag in the forums, I played it with my friend and had no problems at all. And being a huge fencing fan, I think this game is perfect in the format it was made. You really need to approach the fight strategically or you'll get your derrière sistematically handed to you. The game is one hit kill when armed with sword and when disarmed if your opponent strikes you on the ground he'll snap your neck and kill you, but this is just a mean to an end, since your main goal ain't to kill your opponent but to get to the last screen you need to push to be devoured by the mythical serpent Nidhogg, hence the name of the game, and to do that you need to kill you enemy and  move forward through each screen, being lead to a fence-fueled tug of war. And the graphics, soundtrack and sound effects match the game perfectly and until now I didn't experienced any major flaws on the gameplay of the game which is fluid and easy to get the hang. The single-player can be fun enough, but the game really shines in the multiplayer, the local versus can make for a really neat party game. So scrap some cash and buy this gem.

reviewText:
Wow, well that was short...
I was under the impression this game would be a fun and frantic sword-em-up where I run through level upon level fighting similar sword wielding stick-men.
Fun? Admittedly yes, and the combat system requires precision and timing. If you fail, it was your fault, but when you succeed, you know you earned it.
Swords? Yea, there's a f*ck-ton. I gave it an extra point in the score just for this reason
Level upon level? Here's where we nosedive... There are four... And they're not long. The 12 or 16 stages that make up the singleplayer shamelessly reuse the levels, making progress repetitive.
I'd go on but I'm being given *the stare* for not ironing my shirt. So we'll leave it at this:

With completion in just under 2hrs of total play time, and a default cost of £10.99! A worthwhile purchase this game is not. [4.0]

reviewText:
A truly fun game with very smooth gameplay. There's not much singleplayer content other than fighting a line of swordmen with the difficulty increase per time you defeat the next in the row. The multiplayer seems to have a bit delay for now, other than that it's great fun killing your enemy. Your goal is to get to the right of the level and enter the next screen, while your enemy have to get to the left side of the screen. You are only able to move to the next scene when  you have the GO sign in the opposite corner of yourself, It's a tough process and can take a good amount of time if you're playing against a mighty fencer.

There are various ways to kill and disarm your enemy or yourself :3
You have 5 different ways to hold your sword, with different range depending on you're trying to target the enemies feet or head. The higher you aim, the longer range. The lower you aim, the shorter range.
When holding the sword in the upper position, you'll be able to throw it (also when jumping in midair), hopefully killing your enemy or die trying...
When you jump, you're able to strike downward, this is a great ability if you've lost your sword and still want to go offensive on your enemy. You can also roll and kick when approaching the player if his sword is in a high position, else you'll just die horribly by getting stacked in the chest or face.

The sound effects makes it quite enjoyable to stick your sword through the chest of someone else and keeping it inside, making it bleed"  more and enemy scream even longer is just very satisfying.

The different set of levels gives the player a good amount of space to use his different moves and feature lots of movement to make the scenes more alive
date:
the game does have music but it's quite ambient and might not get noticed because of the  screams coming from either you or your enemy.

.:CONCLUSION:.
It's really good fun and plays great
recommended: the price point might be a bit high but there's online multiplayer which makes the price acceptable in my opinion. There's not much content for the single-player type and the online multi-player can be slighty laggy at times but based on being very unique
hoursPlayed: play very smooth and the gameplay have great combat
voteText: I would very much recommend this game."

reviewText:
Nidhogg, I first heard about this Indie game through TheDiamondMinecart at Insomnia 53. SkyDoesMinecraft, TheDiamondMinecart, Antvenom and AshleyMariee participated in a little Indie games challenge. They played Lethal League, SpeedRunners and Nidhogg. It was an absolutely fantastic performance.

Oh, I absolutely love the funktionality in Nidhogg! The controls are hard at first but after a while they flow so easily. Sword fighting for me has never been this fun in any game I've ever played before. This is better than Minecraft PVP in my opinion. The background & asthetics flow right along with the duel perfectly! I absolutely love it. I fell kind of addicted now!

I've never seen a fighting style game quite like tNidhogghis. It's a little bit like Capcom style but with more realistic machanics and more appealing. I didn't say realistic graphics though, it's really fun in an Atari kind of way while keeping all it's own style. There is a lot of background detail. I say detail even though it's pixel art. It's EXTREME pixel art. It's really well designed, for my tastes anyway.

A couple cons are that there aren't that many maps, only four. Another one is that there are not as many offence forms as I think there could be while still keeping it simple. All in all, it's a great game. I rate it four & a half out of five stars.
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game is pure fun! It can't really be described, other than fast paced fencing-martial arts-divekicking-combat - oh yea, and you get eaten by a huge wyrm at the end of every level to top it all off.

The combat system is unique, in that there is surprising depth for such a seemly short (and by short, I mean a ton of deaths every level. This game isn't exactly easy) single player game. Developing your own style really feels like you own it, and every time you die, you don't feel cheated.

Multiplayer is where this game really shines, and it's really meant to be played against a human opponent, whether someone online or someone sitting beside you. The CPU opponents put up a great fight though, and it's perfect for developing your own style of play before you face off with a friend.

The price is slightly high, for what this game is, but if you feel like it's something you might enjoy, I would say possibly wait for a sale if you are strapped for cash.

That being said, I do not regret my purchase. To me personally, this game is worth it.
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText: The adrenaline will fly as you try to overtake your opponent in Nidhogg! The object of the game is to reach the other side of the map, to which there are seven sections; the only thing stopping you is your little set of legs and your adversary. There is a surprising amount of depth to this one on one side scroller, despite the only controls being jump, attack and the directions. You can hold your sword in three positions: high, medium, or low. Where you hold the sword dictates what attacks you will block.\n\nAll throughout you will have to make split-second decisions, and those decisions are what make the game so addicting. At times, you will be convinced that you have felled the enemy, only to be rolled into and killed. These are the defining moments of Nidhogg; while your jaw is on the floor from the surprise, your stinker of a roommate hoofs it to the goal.

reviewText:
It might look like hot garbage, or art, depending on where you fall in terms of visual preference. It might be stupidly simple, or elegantly uncomplex, depending on how you feel about the gameplay. It might be the greatest fighting game ever made, or an overpriced hipster art project, depending on if you like the damn thing or not. In development since 2011, this side-scrolling two-player fighting game where you duel with swords, kicks, runs, jumps and fistfights has been turning heads. Either towards it, attracted to the bright Atari-style low-fi graphics and immediately comprehensible combat, or away from it in disgust because… reasons.

It’s an incredible fast paced game when both players (or the player vs A.I.) are reckless. Pixel blood flows down the walls as each fighter tries to get past the other. If you make it, you move to the next screen and your opponent is placed in front of you once more. It’s a tug of war, in a sense. The victor not decided by who kills who the most, but by whichever side reaches their goal first: a giant flying worm on either end of the level. If you can get eaten by the Nidhogg, you have proven your prowess in combat.

But it can also be a slow, methodical and beautiful game of lethal Chess.

reviewText:
It's a bit frustrating trying to learn with no experience, but after a few matches when you start to get it down the game becomes incredibly addictive. I don't have too much time on the game currently simply because I just purchased it a few days ago (just before the sale >_>), but I think I can speak for all of us saying you don't need to have played very long to know how great of a game this is.

I'm generally a very competetive person and hate to lose, or to even have a challenge, but difficulty in this game is really healthy and incredibly fun.

My rating: 8/10
+ simple, quick matches.
+ something you can play over and over.
+ yes, there *is* online matchmaking with friends and with randoms.
+ built-in tournament bracket for large groups of friends (up to 8 players)
+ I loooove rolling and cartwheeling.

just the little things:
- throwing swords can be a bit tricky sometimes if you're trying to do it quickly.
- I wish you could choose your character's color, though this isn't anything big enough to sway my rating, just a thought
- only 4 maps can get a bit tiresome sometimes, and I wish there was a random selection option as well

reviewText:
I learned about Nidhogg after I played a game based off of Nidhogg, back when Nidhogg wasn't even released yet. The game was called Eggnogg, and it was said to be the closest thing to what Nidhogg was probably going to be. At the time, people couldn't get enough of what they saw of Nidhogg, and they really couldn't wait for it to finally come out, so much so that they would start making games based of it.

When Nidhogg was finally released, I had already forgotten about it, having had my fill of copies and games based off of the copies.

I did remember this game again, eventually. I won it in a giveaway, and now here I am. The game fulfills a lot of promises, for me. And I jump and stab my way through the stages, listening to engaging music, shouting at my opponent in anger and glee. It's all around fun that I'm sure I'll get every time I load the game.

Get Nidhogg, play it with your friends, stab someone in the face, and sacrifice yourself to the great dragon while having lots of fun. I know I am.

10/10

It’s an incredible fast paced game when both players (or the player vs A.I.) are reckless. Pixel blood flows down the walls as each fighter tries to get past the other. If you make it, you move to the next screen and your opponent is placed in front of you once more. It’s a tug of war, in a sense. The victor not decided by who kills who the most, but by whichever side reaches their goal first: a giant flying worm on either end of the level. If you can get eaten by the Nidhogg, you have proven your prowess in combat.

But it can also be a slow, methodical and beautiful game of lethal Chess.

reviewText:
Nidhogg, where do I start. Not much content, graphics simple yet fitting, laggy multiplayer, a seemingly boring soundtrack, and pretty decent combat. Fifteen dollars is not worth the lack of content this game provides, unless you have friends who live in your house, as tournaments are only local. The lack of maps is another downside to this game, but can be overlooked, as the maps included do have noticable differences. Swordplay is interesting, and takes some work to master. Matchmaking turns out to be horrendous unless you have friends to play with, as the matchmaking takes ten minutes to find a match, but when you do it is enjoyable. The gameplay provided is minimal, but what is provided is enjoyable. Overall, this title is not one for those who don't wish to put the work in to learn to master the excellent swordplay presented to them, but fifteen dollars is too much, this game is worth five or less.

If however you do decide to purchase this game, watch the first duel in this video, as it shows all the tricks needed to suceed in Nidhogg

reviewText:
While it is an enjoyable game with an original playstyle and tight as ♥♥♥♥ controls, I cannot recommend it. The single player is boring with only 4 maps and little variation between opponents, with only a single gamemode. Multiplayer was good fun but the developers managed to ♥♥♥♥ it up somehow in the new update so playing with friends is virtually impossible.

Asking £10.99 for this small game is an insult as it only provided some brief entertainment before I became bored and tired of the concept. I understand that this was a kickstarter project so I would rate this game 9/11, because it is suspicous and requires futher investigation.

It looks like the devs pocketed all the money and then released small uninspired updates which add no actual content but instead break a fun little game. It's horrendously overpriced and has broken multiplayer.

reviewText:
Nidhogg solely focus on a combat system, combining fencing and tug-of-war together to create a simple yet fun gameplay. There are a lot of options there to create a strategy. You can fight your opponent with rapier or goes unarmed, you can thrust, punch, parry, disarm opponent, throwing weapon, do a sweep attack, and even do a dive kick. Running away also a one good strategy here in Nidhogg for you to consider as the objective is to reach the goal not to defeat the opponent until he/she run out of life.

Nidhogg's concept is good and the video that show is even help make it look very interesting.

Anyway, one big flaw of Nighogg is a lacks of contents, especially in a lacks of solid single player content. The only thing you will find in a single player mode is a series of 16 AI opponents that not really different in terms of difficulty, pretty much the same. There are only 4 stages in the game as you can see in the video. No unloackable contents pretty much make this game suffer a scarceness of solid contents and no replay value.

It is true that the core design of the game is quite interesting. I am able to enjoy a single player mode to some extent but that's that. Once I beat the single player mode I went to try multiplayer mode with someone, unfortunately online matchmaking show that no one playing Nidhogg online and none of my fried owned this game as well.

I guess the game could deliver a better experience if you has a friend to play together offline or online but for a gamer who focus on single player experience I recommend you to avoid Nidhogg. Even with a 66% discount for this game is seem a little pricy to me after I bought it.

reviewText:
Nidhogg is nice for the first few hours within which you'll probably repeatedly fight the singleplayer AI until you release it's occasionally either far too stupid or far too difficult (it can do things that you simply cannot), at which point you'll probably feel experienced enough to try the multiplayer.

It's at this point that the game completely falls apart. The multiplayer is consistently laggy and it always seems to take at least a few minutes to get into a match - if finding a game wasn't arduous enough, attempting to transfer your SP tactics to MP is nigh impossible since you'll find the controls simply aren't responsive enough. Nidhogg absolutely requires you to have quick reactions and MP makes this impossible.

The Tournament mode is useless without at least two other experienced players able to use your computer (since it's local MP) and if you were looking to practice against the AI then enjoy having to play through the entire game just to get to a point you feel is difficult enough because you can't skip levels.

Oh, and the super bright cloud level is absolutely horrible to look at, I personally can barely see anything. I wonder how exactly the development time on this game was spent when there are such obvious flaws (why would you choose a bright background when the player is bright yellow and the sword is white?)

I do honestly like the gameplay but I can't in all good conscience recommend this game to anyone looking for a competitive multiplayer experience. Some cool stuff can happen but on average, Nidhogg will leave you simultaneously annoyed but wanting to play more since it could get better.

reviewText: Nidhogg is a two player fencing duel to the death, where each player attempts to defeat the other repeatedly as they head to the opposite side of the stage from their starting position to be eaten by the dragon at the end of the world. No, really. There's a single player mode, but it's not where the game shines. The AI is unpolished, as it occasionally goes dumb and lets you mow it down. Far better is beating a friend in person. The netcode for the game is currently (as of release day) a bit rough and confers quite a host advantage at the moment.\n\nDon't let that deter you. Grab it now while it's 20% off and get to stabbin' your friends!

reviewText:
This game is just pure AWESOME!

The combat is pefectly exicuted and every death that happens to you can't be blamed by hacks or what not, you have to strategize EVERY move you make before you strike.

Singleplayer may feel empty to some but it was an absolute pleasure trying to beat my own time!

The How To Play section is a bit buggy (at the moment) but I'm sure there will be a fix. Even though you can play the game, test the controls, and see what works for you! I didn't even realize there was such a mode and I mastered the controls in just 5 minutes of trial and error play!

And then you can play multiplayer locally AND online.

Easily one of the best games I've ever played!

Addicting, hair pulling, and fun to the last pixelated drop of blood!       10/10
voteText: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Nidhogg is absurdly fun.  The combat is similar to Divekick with its simple controls and surprising amount of depth in combat.  Once you kill your opponent you'll only have a few seconds to get as far as you can before you respawn.  Then you must decide if you're gonna take down your opponent again or try to run past him and go for the goal Randy Moss style.

Nidhogg is not without its issues though.  There's nothing for PC specific options aside from volume sliders and the online play has a few issues which could potentially be a dealbreaker.

Creating a lobby at first was an exercise in frustration.  The invite friends list is not alphabatized which isn't a huge deal if you don't have many Steam friends, but I have 200+ and it added extra time to what should be a simple process.  Once you invite someone the other person doesn't get a Steam notification, they have to hit Join Game" from Steam friends.  There's no indication that you have to do this either.  Once you have this all figured out it works
date: but come on.  These are basic menu functions in any online game.\n\nIn the games I played with my friend the host had a huge advantage because of latency
recommended: we had to swap hosting every few rounds to make it fair.  If you can play locally then you won't have to deal with this.  It's a perfect couch game if you are thinking of a Steambox solution.\n\nDespite my complaints about the game I've really enjoyed it so far
hoursPlayed:
though with the issues I've mentioned above it's a little hard to recommend at full price.  Buy it on sale for sure.

TL;DR version:  Buy if you have a friend to play with and can deal with a few online issues.

EDIT

1/14/2014 - The invite system works with Steam properly now

reviewText: Incredibly fun, fast-paced, fencing duels galore. The visuals and music are great and the gameplay, although simple to learn, is challenging to master. Not to mention hilarious with a group of friends. Nothing makes you feel more badass than timing a sword throw to the face or stabbing your foe in the chest and twisting it back and forth as you revel in victory.\n\nNow that I have said that, probably the biggest problem with this game would have to be the incredibly steep price tag. I bought it when it was about $11 and I regret it for even that price. There are TONS of games that are much cheaper and have waaaay more replayability. There is absolutely nothing justifying its ridiculous price. There are only 3 stages (or 4 I can't quite remember at the moment), a laughable tacked-on single player mode, and barely working multiplayer. Don't get me wrong, the game is fun, it's just not worth 15 freaking bucks. There isn't nearly enough content to warrant a 15 dollar price tag (or even $11 for that matter). Whoever decided that must have been on drugs. The game as it is should be priced at around 5-6 bucks. If it was around that price I would recommend everyone to get it. For the time being I honestly feel pretty cheated out of my money. If it was cheaper the devs would make more money for it in the end, I am almost positive everyone on my friends list would have bought it. Not to mention the multiplayer would have more value since there would be more people to fight. Also it only supports 360 controllers which sucks.

reviewText:
TL;DR: Buy for local mutiplayer only.

I don't really know how I can express my hatred toward this game. The worst part about that, is that it is quite a good game.
The game is funny to play with friend for a time, graphics and music are very well made.

But first, the game looks extremely aggressive, there is always a flickering element in any moment of the game and it flickers quite fast too, graphics are gory and depict many things not nice to watch.
Second thing, the content is very low, 4 maps, you can't change players colours.
Third thing, the AI is very badly done, it is not funny at all to play single player.
Another thing I need to add, the game sometimes doesn't care if you modify your control setup and sometimes doesn't register some of your inputs, playing this game is kinda playing lotery: you know it can be nice but if you try too much it will most certainly brings more pain than pleasure.
Last thing online mutiplayer is very crappy.

To conclude, this game is good so if you want to take it consider only for local battles with friends and only a few times.

For people who are willing to rate this review down, I am willing to hear why.

reviewText:
I personally loved this game, it encompasses so much that I use to love as a child all in one package.

The game plays like a mix between Marshmellow Duels (an old DOS based Super smash Brlos styled game) and Prince of Persia Classic (I doubt this needs exaplining)

The game might look simple and to be honest it is and it isn't. The amazing thing about this game is when you play as a noob with another noob you can pretty much have fun screwing up togther. If you are both hardcore u can stay minutes on one level, and feel your adrenaline rush.

Now if you play as a noob against a good player expect the match to be over ina  matter of seconds in some cases. The game is simple but it's also very skill friendly, so if your good > bad players and luck plays very little here.

There are only a hand full of levels but you will want to keep playing them over and over again. The online and local multiplayer is where the game shines. It turns this great game into a fantastic game. You will only play with Ai when you have no internet or people over, other than that you will never want to vs ai again.

9.0/10 at full price

9.5/10 on sale

The reason for different scores is because the game is fairly expensive for what it offers, but the mechanics are so clean and simple that it can make up for it even at full price for some.

If your not a fan of retro or fencing styled games (ninja fencing in this case) don't bother with this game. It's graphics are charming to those that can appreciate them, and the game play to those that love the genre:)

reviewText:
I personally loved this game, it encompasses so much that I use to love as a child all in one package.

The game plays like a mix between Marshmellow Duels (an old DOS based Super smash Brlos styled game) and Prince of Persia Classic (I doubt this needs exaplining)

The game might look simple and to be honest it is and it isn't. The amazing thing about this game is when you play as a noob with another noob you can pretty much have fun screwing up togther. If you are both hardcore u can stay minutes on one level, and feel your adrenaline rush.

Now if you play as a noob against a good player expect the match to be over ina  matter of seconds in some cases. The game is simple but it's also very skill friendly, so if your good > bad players and luck plays very little here.

There are only a hand full of levels but you will want to keep playing them over and over again. The online and local multiplayer is where the game shines. It turns this great game into a fantastic game. You will only play with Ai when you have no internet or people over, other than that you will never want to vs ai again.

9.0/10 at full price

9.5/10 on sale

The reason for different scores is because the game is fairly expensive for what it offers, but the mechanics are so clean and simple that it can make up for it even at full price for some.

If your not a fan of retro or fencing styled games (ninja fencing in this case) don't bother with this game. It's graphics are charming to those that can appreciate them, and the game play to those that love the genre:)

reviewText: Nidhogg is a very simplistic representation of fencing where the goal is to reach the opponent's start point and get eaten by some giant creature presumably called the Nidhogg. The gameplay has a bit of a tug-of-war feel to it as dead players respawn a bit further back from where they were slain meaning you have to continuously battle all the way to the end without failing to win. Combat consists of moving your blade up/down, thrusting, rolling, throwing the blade, and jump kicks, combinations of which can be used to confuse and disable your opponent, setting them up for the kill. Once you kill an opponent, you gain the right of way and place him on the defensive, meaning that if you were to jump over him and continue towards his start, he would have to pursue you or allow himself to be scrolled off and respawn in front of you.\n\nDue to the overall simplicity of the game and small number of levels, it seems to suit itself more towards multiplayer than single player which is unfortunate because the multiplayer can get downright unplayable due to latency causing your inputs to get ignored or delayed. Additionally the controls can be awkward when shifting between stances not to mention you risk throwing your sword when shifting to stab high from a mid-stance. I originally had a bit more positive of a review for this game but after re-playing it I decided to drop my recommendation since the content is really lacking and not worth the base price (or really even the sale price).

reviewText:
This game is the ♥♥♥♥.

It's a fast-paced two-player dueling game. You can fence madly, cartwheel away, throw your rapier, somersault through the air, snatch a rapier off the ground and skewer your opponent through the guts, you can rush unarmed at your opponent only to roll beneath his drawn rapier at the last moment, trip him with  a sweep of the leg, tear his heart out, grab his rapier and keep running. You can pull off all kinds of insane stunts, and I can't help but laugh every time. This gameplay is accompanied by an equally frenzied soundtrack and trippy neon graphics. The great art direction and style of this game is undeniable.

Multiplayer is online and local, and there is also a singleplayer mode where you fight a computer opponent. It's not as fun as desperately outsmarting a human opponent. The online multiplayer introduces a ton of lag and causes many maneuvers to be impossible to pull off. That said, I've been mainly playing online opponents (haven't had the chance to play local yet), and it's been some of the most exhilarating multiplayer gameplay I've experienced, despite the lag.

There aren't many games where you can do a somersault, but this is one of them. It feels great.

On the downside, there are only 4 stages. What you'll get out of this game will depend on how much you put into it and on the people you play against. Best suited for playing with friends, two controllers and a tv.
